Every tiger in the world is unique â€“ no two tigers have the same pattern of stripes.
Camel humps store fat, which will be used as an energy source when food is not available.
Penguins closer to the equator eat more fish and penguins closer to Antarctica eat more squid and krill.
The Cheetah is the fastest land animal in the world and can reach 112km/h in just three seconds.
Female kangaroos sport a pouch on their belly to cradle baby kangaroos, called joeys.
Despite their huge size and strength, Rhinos are herbivores and eat lots of grass and plants.
Eagles have amazing eyesight and can detect prey up to two miles away.
Crocodiles have webbed feet which allow them to make fast turns and sudden moves in the water.
Bears are very smart and have been known to roll rocks into bear traps to set them off and eat the bait in safety.
